#text: A dichotomous and an interactive key to the species of
) in America, north of Mexico are presented. A diagnosis accompanied by images is provided for male and female wasps of each of the four species,
), is found worldwide and comprises 234 described species in eight genera (
). Though hypothesized to have originated in the northern hemisphere (
), the diversity of this subfamily is heavily biased to the tropics with nearly half of the species belonging to the circumtropical genus,
are generally large in size and some of the most impressive specimens occur in the cosmopolitan genus

). The majority of the 37 described species in this genus occur in the Oriental region and the Eastern Palearctic. A handful of species occur in each of the following regions: Western Palearctic, Nearctic and Australasian; with one record for both the Neotropical (Chiapas) and Afrotropical regions (
), they are a common sight in the forests of the United States and Canada. Members of this genus are ectoparasitoid idiobionts of wood-boring siricid larvae (
(Cresson), is an effective biocontrol agent employed by the National
Coordination Committee to control the invasive woodwasp,

). Characteristics such as their bright coloration and large size place these spectacular insects among the ‘charismatic megafauna’ of the arthropod world, often capturing the attention of hobbyists and nature enthusiasts. Given the frequency with which non-specialists encounter and work with species of
, image-rich dichotomous and interactive keys will increase the accuracy of identifications.
found in the United States and Canada are broadly distributed across the region (
). The only species native to more southern regions is
(Linneaus) which is also found in Mexico (
now occurs in Australia, New Zealand and South Africa where it was introduced as a biological control agent (
). Siricid wood wasps native to north America are the common hosts of each of the four species (
also parasitizing the invasive wood wasp,
A key to the genera of Nearctic
, illustrated with high quality color images, is available online at
. Here, we present a key to the four Nearctic species, designed for use by non-specialists. We have adopted some characters from previous keys (

) in addition to creating our own when necessary. This key will be linked to the website of the American Entomological Institute where it will complement its generic key. It will also be advertised on the popular website
to promote its use by the general public.
Type specimens for each species were checked for the diagnostic morphological characters assigned by
. A broad range of specimens from the hundreds of

housed in the Kentucky and American Entomological Institute collections were examined. Characters included in the keys were chosen based on the ease with which they could be assessed by a non-specialist.

tbody.#text: A. Metasoma melanic (blackish-brown) and lacking yellow markings; ovipositor sheath about 3.7 times as long as fore wing
(Fabricius)
B. Metasoma ranging from brown to reddish-brown with conspicuous bright yellow markings; ovipositor sheath 1.8 to 3 times as long as fore wing
A. Well-defined, yellow, roundish spot on each of tergites 4-6
(Cresson)
B. Angled yellow bands on each of tergites 4-6
A. Vertical black stripe on face below each antennal socket; ovipositor sheath about 3 times as long as fore wing
(Linnaeus)
B. Vertical stripes on face absent; ovipositor sheath about 1.8 times as long as fore wing
Viereck
A. Fore wing marked with brown patch at base of cell 2R1
(Linnaeus)
B. Fore wing lacking brown patch at base of cell 2R1
A. Mesopleuron blackish brown with yellow spot below wing insertion, no additional yellow markings
(Cresson)
B. Mesopleuron ranging from blackish brown to reddish-brown, yellow spot below wing insertion and additional yellow markings
A. Mesosoma color reddish-brown and yellow
Viereck
B. Mesosoma color blackish-brown and yellow
(Fabricius)

#text: include the presence of a petiolate triangular areolet on the fore wing, a longitudinal ridge on the trochantellus of the middle leg and lateral tubercles on the apical margin of the clypeus. In addition, tergites 3–5 of female
are smooth to punctate and sternites 2–6 possess a pair of tubercles close to the anterior sternal margin. Male

have a strong setiferous groove which is close to and paralleling the apical 0.7 of the ventral interior margin; and tergites 3–6 are strongly concave apically and possess a median apical or subapical longitudinal submembranous area. These male specific characters are not well developed in small specimens and they may key to the genus
Thunberg, 1822; 1824. Acad. Imp. des Sci. St. Petersburg, Mem.8: 266; 9: 322. Unnecessarily proposed n. name for
Lepeletier, Hist. Nat. Ins. Hym., v. 4, p. 78.

treatment-sec.title: Distinguishing characters.
p: Female: Head and antenna mostly yellow, may or may not have a dark spot above the clypeus. Mesosoma and metasoma black. Mesosoma sometimes with a small yellow spot on posterodorsal corner of pronotum, rarely with yellow markings. Fore wing 15 to 30 mm long; wings infuscate or entirely black. Ovipositor sheath about 3.7 times as long as forewing.
Females may be distinguished from the other species occurring in the USA and Canada by their body color.

Male. Head yellow, may or may not have a dark spot above the clypeus. Mesosoma yellow and blackish brown; metasoma very dark brown to black with a yellow mark on the hind margin of the first tergite; wings hyaline, fore wing 16 to 22 mm long.

#text: by the evenly darkened fore wing and the lack of a brown patch at the base of cell 2R1; from
by the additional yellow markings on the mesopleuron; and from
by the color of the mesosoma.
Smith, N. J. State Mus., Ann. Rpt. for 1909, p. 627. Nomen nudum.

Most specimens are found in the eastern Nearctic to about longitude 96 °W, with some found as far west as Wyoming (

treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
p: Female: Head mostly yellow; mesosoma reddish-brown and yellow. Metasoma reddish-brown, each tergite with an angled yellow band; bands on the third and following tergites interrupted on the midline. Fore wing 12 to 27 mm long. Wings hyaline and the fore wing usually with a large brown patch at the base of cell 2R1. Ovipositor sheath about 1.8 times as long as fore wing.

#text: by their reddish-brown and yellow body color; from
by the angled yellow bands on their metasoma; and from
by the lack of vertical stripes on the face.

p: Male: Head mostly yellow; mesosoma reddish-brown and yellow; metasoma reddish-brown with yellow and black markings on first two or three tergites. Wings hyaline; fore wing 10 to 16 mm long.

#text: by the lack of vertical stripes on the face.
Kriechbaumer, 1890. Wien, Mus. der Naturgesch., Ann. 5: 487. Preocc. in

nomenclature-citation.comment: Megerle, 1803. Appendix ad Cat. Ins., Quae Mense Novembris 1802 Vienne Austriae Auctionis Lege Vendita Fuere, p. 16.

#text: The specific epithet macrura is commonly applied to this species, however the name
as a noun and therefore is not required to match the gender of the genus name.
is found in Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah.
ranges across the eastern Nearctic to the eastern slopes of the Rocky Mountains.
extends from Florida to south-western Texas, and has been collected in Mexico (Chihuahua).

treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
p: Female. Head yellow and dark brown, with two vertical stripes on face, one below each antennal socket. Mesosoma and metasoma ranging from dark brown to reddish-brown and yellow. Each tergite with an angled yellow band interrupted on the third to sixth tergites. Wings hyaline with brown patches; fore wing 18 to 29 mm long. Ovipositor sheath about 3.0 times as long as fore wing.

#text: by the angled yellow bands on the tergites; and from
by the vertical stripes on the face.

p: Male. Head yellow and dark brown, with two vertical stripes on face, one below each antennal socket. Mesosoma yellow and blackish brown, metasoma brown, first and second tergites with a short yellow band on hind margin. Wings hyaline, fore wing 7 to 21 mm long with a brown patch at the base of cell 2R1.
Males can be distinguished from the other species occurring in the USA and Canada by the brown patch at the base of cell 2R1 of the fore wing and the presence of two vertical stripes on the face.

nomenclature-citation.comment: Dalla Torre, 1901. Cat. Hym., v. 3, p. 481. Emendation.

#text: is distributed along the Pacific Coast from south-western Canada to California, and extends eastward to central Colorado.

is found in the north-eastern U.S. and adjacent parts of Canada. In the late 1960s and early 1970s this species was collected across the United States and Canada, encompassing the ranges of both subspecies, for introduction as a biocontrol agent in Australia (
). The populations established in Australia were then introduced to South Africa (

treatment-sec.title: Diagnosis.
p: Female. Head black to blackish brown and yellow; mesosoma black or blackish brown, with yellow spots; metasoma brown and usually a little paler than me

sosoma. Subtriangular median subapical spot on first and second tergites, large round yellow spot on side of tergites 3-5, and vertical yellow blotch on side of sixth and seventh tergites. Fore wing 13 to 29 mm long. Ovipositor sheath about 2.7 times as long as fore wing.

#text: by the body color; and from
by the yellow spots on the tergites.

p: Male. Head black to blackish brown and yellow; mesosoma black to blackish brown, with yellow spots; metasoma brown, the tergites usually darker medially; the first two tergites with a median subapical yellow spot. Fore wing 9.5 to 20 mm long.

#text: by the lack of a brown patch at the base of cell 2R1 of the fore wing and from
by the single vertical black band on the face and the color of the mesopleuron.

. The authors also thank the Museum für Naturkunde Berlin for their support in the publication of the manuscript.
